For the Midterm Assignment, you will do a presentation based on at least 2 reading sources.
https://www.edwardtesol.com/uploads/2/6/5/8/26581579/midterm_presentations_info_and_guide.pdf

The homework for next class is to choose, read, and bring one reading source to discuss. The source can be from a report, research paper, book, essay, reliable website, or article. See the list of source options in pink.
 You can choose any topic. I suggest choose something you are interested in and related to your major. Try to be specific. See topic examples below in blue. 
 Here is a list of places to find reading sources.
Academic Papers & Journals
Google Scholar – Great for finding papers; sometimes links to free PDFs.
Semantic Scholar – AI-powered search with many open-access papers.
arXiv – Preprints in computer science, AI, physics, and more.
Directory of Open Access Journals (DOAJ) – Free, peer-reviewed journals across disciplines.
CORE – Aggregates millions of open-access research articles.
PubMed Central – Free access to biomedical and health-related papers.
Books & Texts
Internet Archive – Millions of free books, papers, and media.
Project Gutenberg – Free classic literature and reference books.
OpenStax – Free, peer-reviewed textbooks (math, science, humanities).
OAPEN Library – Open-access academic books, many in humanities and social sciences.
PDF Drive – Search engine for free PDF books (quality varies).
Research Data & Statistics
Our World in Data – Free datasets and visuals on global issues.
Kaggle – Free datasets, especially for AI and data science.
UN Data – Official United Nations statistics.
World Bank Open Data – Economic and social data worldwide.
More General Knowledge
Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy – Free, reliable philosophy/ethics reference.
The Conversation – Articles written by academics, free and accessible.
PLOS ONE – Open-access scientific journal.
 Here is a list of example topics for your presentation:
1. Programming & Technical Sides
Python vs. Other Languages in AI: Why Python is preferred in machine learning, but how R, Julia, or C++ might be better in certain cases.
The Limitations of ChatGPT in Coding Help: When AI generates errors, insecure code, or outdated solutions.
Energy Costs of Training Models: The environmental footprint of training GPT-4 compared with Google searches.
2. Ethics & Controversies
AI Scraping and Copyright: The lawsuits against OpenAI and Stability AI for using books and images without permission.
Bias in AI Systems: Examples like facial recognition misidentifying people of color, or hiring algorithms filtering out women’s résumés.
Deepfake Dangers: Political misinformation and celebrity impersonation scandals.
3. Society & Everyday Life
AI in Education: How students use ChatGPT for homework, and the debate about plagiarism vs. support.
AI and Jobs: Which jobs are most likely to be replaced (e.g., call centers, translators) vs. new jobs being created (AI ethics officers, prompt engineers).
AI in Healthcare: How AI diagnoses cancers earlier than doctors, but also the risks of misdiagnosis.
AI in Social Media: Recommendation algorithms shaping what we see on TikTok, YouTube, or Instagram.
4. Future & Philosophy
Self-Driving Cars: Why Tesla’s Autopilot struggles in some conditions; should humans or AI take final control?
Can AI Be Creative?: Comparing an AI-generated painting or song with a human artist’s work.
The “Black Box” Problem: Why we can’t always explain how deep learning models make decisions.
AI for Global Challenges: Using AI to predict climate patterns or discover new medicines.
5. Broader Tech Topics (linked to AI)
Cybersecurity Risks with AI: Hackers using AI to generate phishing emails or fake voices.
Blockchain + AI: Using blockchain to verify AI-generated content.
Open-Source vs. Closed AI: Stability AI’s open models vs. OpenAI’s closed ones — what’s better for innovation?
The Carbon Footprint of Data Centers: Comparing AI model training to airline emissions.
